issue.title: [question] VirtualRunEnv does not take tool_requires into account?
issue.body:
### What is your question?

Hi, I am currently migrating to Conan 2 (i.e. 2.0.12) and facing issues with the `VirtualRunEnv` generator when using `gcc` as a conan package which is obviously needed in the `buildenv` but also in the `runenv`, since it also provides libs like e.g. `libstdc++.so` and the like. 
My understanding was that in Conan 2 the generator automatically takes care of propagating `libdirs` to `LD_LIBRARY_PATH` in the `runenv`. But this is apparently not the case for `tool_requires`, although I expected this to be the reason why `tool_requires` sets the trait `run=True`.

Specifically I first encountered the issue when building `geographiclib` (https://github.com/conan-io/conan-center-index/blob/master/recipes/geographiclib/all/test_package/conanfile.py). I provide the compiler dependency using a profile like this:
```
[settings]
compiler=gcc
compiler.version=11.4
compiler.libcxx=libstdc++11

[tool_requires]
gcc/11.4.0@me/testing
```

Building `geographiclib` works fine, but executing the test package leads to the following error:

```
======== Testing the package: Executing test ========
geographiclib/1.52@me/testing (test package): Running test()
geographiclib/1.52@me/testing (test package): RUN: ./test_package
./test_package: /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libstdc++.so.6: version `GLIBCXX_3.4.29' not found (required by /home/me/.conan2/p/b/geogr35b2f1e80aeb9/p/lib/libGeographic.so.19)

ERROR: geographiclib/1.52@me/testing (test package): Error in test() method, line 26
        self.run(bin_path, env="conanrun")
        ConanException: Error 1 while executing
```

Obviously the `libdir` of `gcc` is not part of the `LD_LIBRARY_PATH` and instead of the `libstdc++.so` provided by the conan package the system one is found during runtime, which does not match the version from compilation.

This can be mitigated by hacking an explicit runtime dependency into the test package like `self.requires("gcc/11.4.0@me/stable", run=True)`. Then executing the test executable in the `conanrun` env works. But this is just a hack.

From looking at the code in `conan/tools/env/virtualrunenv.py` in the `environment()` method, I see that only `host` and `test` dependencies are taken into account for the env: 

```
        host_req = self._conanfile.dependencies.host
        test_req = self._conanfile.dependencies.test
        for require, dep in list(host_req.items()) + list(test_req.items()):
            if dep.runenv_info:
                runenv.compose_env(dep.runenv_info)
            if require.run:  # Only if the require is run (shared or application to be run)
                _os = self._conanfile.settings.get_safe("os")
                runenv.compose_env(runenv_from_cpp_info(dep, _os))
```

But those `host` and `test` properties directly filter for `build=False` which obviously does not take `tool_requires` into account which use `build=True`. See `conans/model/dependencies.py` line 138:

```
    @property
    def host(self):
        return self.filter({"build": False, "test": False, "skip": False})

    @property
    def test(self):
        # Not needed a direct_test because they are visible=False so only the direct consumer
        # will have them in the graph
        return self.filter({"build": False, "test": True, "skip": False})
```

Now, is there a misunderstanding on my side? I would have expected that since `tool_requires` sets `run=True`, those should also be reflected in the `VirtualRunEnv`. Generally I think all dependecies with `run=True` should be reflected in the `VirtualRunEnv`.
Indeed changing the code in `conan/tools/env/virtualrunenv.py` to something like this, makes is work as I expected:
```
        host_req = self._conanfile.dependencies.host
        test_req = self._conanfile.dependencies.test
        run_req = self._conanfile.dependencies.filter({"run": True})
        for require, dep in list(host_req.items()) + list(test_req.items()) + list(run_req.items()):
            if dep.runenv_info:
                runenv.compose_env(dep.runenv_info)
            if require.run:  # Only if the require is run (shared or application to be run)
                _os = self._conanfile.settings.get_safe("os")
                runenv.compose_env(runenv_from_cpp_info(dep, _os))
```

What is the best practice here for dependencies needed during build and run?

### Have you read the CONTRIBUTING guide?

- [X] I've read the CONTRIBUTING guide

comment.body:
> You might with a small cheat, avoid that. Like using the tool_requires in the profile, and just running a conan install --requires=gcc/... -g VirtualRunEnv to get the extra env script to inject that runtime? Might need some exploration.

This works for providing the appropriate run time environment for my final end product. But it does not fix the problem in test_packages of conan packages which try to build and execute code which needs the libs from gcc for execution. I don't see a possibility to inject requires here, without hardcoding them in the conanfile of the test_package.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -23,13 +24,18 @@ def config_options(self):
         if self.settings.os == "Windows":
             del self.options.fPIC
 
+    def validate(self):
+        if self.settings.os in ("Windows", "Macos") and self.options.shared:
+            raise ConanException("Windows and Macos needs extra BUILD configuration to be able "
+                                 "to create a shared library. Please, check this reference to "
+                                 "know more about it: https://bazel.build/reference/be/c-cpp")
+
comment.body: The next PR solves this issue. That one introduces changes in the template to let users create/consume shared libraries in all the platforms.

pull_request.title: [Bazel][1.x][Part 1]: Bazel + BazelToolchain refactor
pull_request.body:
Changelog: Feature: `BazelToolchain` creates a `conan_bzl.rc` file which defines the `conan-config` configuration. If it exists, Bazel helper will use it automatically.
Changelog: `bazel_layout` puts all the Conan files in a separate folder.
Docs: https://github.com/conan-io/docs/pull/XXXX
Closes: https://github.com/conan-io/conan/issues/14282 https://github.com/conan-io/conan/issues/14519

Next PR (BazelDeps): https://github.com/conan-io/conan/pull/14959

Summary:

* **bazel_layout** is now creating all the Conan-generated files inside another folder, `conan`.
     * WORKSPACE file (consumer side) before my change:

      load("@//:dependencies.bzl", "load_conan_dependencies")
      load_conan_dependencies()

     * Now (**BREAKING CHANGE**):

      load("@//conan:dependencies.bzl", "load_conan_dependencies")
      load_conan_dependencies()
  
* **BazelToolchain** is generating a `conan_bzl.rc` file with a `build:conan-config` configuration depending on your settings/options.
* **BazelToolchain** is not generating a real Bazel toolchain (https://bazel.build/extending/toolchains) because they require much more knowledge and expertise in Bazel to make a dynamic Bazel toolchain per user configuration.
* Bazel is moving forward to platforms (https://bazel.build/extending/platforms) for future releases instead of toolchains but it does not imply that BazelToolchain could be incompatible but some changes to inject those platforms constraints in our conan-config configuration.

repo.name: conan
repo.description: Conan - The open-source C/C++ package manager

repo.description: Conan - The open-source C and C++ package manager

pull_request.title: [Bazel][1.x][Part 1]: Bazel + BazelToolchain refactor
pull_request.body:
Changelog: Feature: `BazelToolchain` creates a `conan_bzl.rc` file which defines the `conan-config` configuration. If it exists, Bazel helper will use it automatically.
Changelog: `bazel_layout` puts all the Conan files in a separate folder.
Docs: https://github.com/conan-io/docs/pull/XXXX
Closes: https://github.com/conan-io/conan/issues/14282 https://github.com/conan-io/conan/issues/14519

Next PR (BazelDeps): https://github.com/conan-io/conan/pull/14959

Summary:

* **bazel_layout** is now creating all the Conan-generated files inside another folder, `conan`.
     * WORKSPACE file (consumer side) before my change:

      load("@//:dependencies.bzl", "load_conan_dependencies")
      load_conan_dependencies()

     * Now (**BREAKING CHANGE**):

      load("@//conan:dependencies.bzl", "load_conan_dependencies")
      load_conan_dependencies()
  
* **BazelToolchain** is generating a `conan_bzl.rc` file with a `build:conan-config` configuration depending on your settings/options.
* **BazelToolchain** is not generating a real Bazel toolchain (https://bazel.build/extending/toolchains) because they require much more knowledge and expertise in Bazel to make a dynamic Bazel toolchain per user configuration.
* Bazel is moving forward to platforms (https://bazel.build/extending/platforms) for future releases instead of toolchains but it does not imply that BazelToolchain could be incompatible but some changes to inject those platforms constraints in our conan-config configuration.

issue.title: How to have the dependencies on an offline artifactory ?
issue.body:
### What is your question?

Hello,
I'm starting on artifactory and conan. I would like to use some c++ library like asio, boost, mongo... on a network not connected to the internet (offline).
I instantiated an artifactory on this network. How can I get the sources, package them and send them to my offline artifactory?
I have access to a network with internet from where I can draw the sources of the library.

issue.title: How to have the dependencies on an offline artifactory ?
issue.body:
### What is your question?

Hello,
I'm starting on artifactory and conan. I would like to use some c++ library like asio, boost, mongo... on a network not connected to the internet (offline).
I instantiated an artifactory on this network. How can I get the sources, package them and send them to my offline artifactory?
I have access to a network with internet from where I can draw the sources of the library.

comment.body:
Hello,
Thanks for your help, thanks to the information you gave me, I have actually managed to show the dependencies on my offline server.

issue.title: [question] Best way to use packaged (cross) compiler for building other packages
issue.body:
### What is your question?

I'd like to use GCC (or other compilers) from a conan package. I actually created on and so far, I can use it like this:

```
$ conan install gcc/10.3.0 -g VirtualBuildEnv
$ source conanbuild.sh
$ which x86_64-linux-gnu-gcc
/home/fschoenm/.conan2/p/gcc87bb9f740b25f/p/bin/x86_64-linux-gnu-gcc
```

Now I experimented with using the _gcc_ package via `--tool-requires` and in that case, I can inject a CMake toolchain into my build process. But I don't really want all packages to depend on the package because it makes it difficult to switch compilers. So now I am looking for a different solution of how to use the packaged compiler into my build process:

* Do I just need to know how the compiler executables are called (_x86_64-linux-gnu-gcc_ in this case)?
* Do I have to set environment variables (CC, CXX, ...) in my virtual build environment to use the compiler?
* I there a way to generate/inject a CMake toolchain coming from the compiler package into my Conan runs?

So far I've tried the second approach but it's not really reliable. It also clashes if the profile is already setting environment variables.

Are there any best practices or a manual how to achieve that?

### Have you read the CONTRIBUTING guide?

- [X] I've read the CONTRIBUTING guide

comment.body:
Here I have a small experimental project to bootstrap gcc from conan compiler, using apt-installed gcc compiler.
https://github.com/AndreyMlashkin/minimalistic_conan_docker

issue.title: [question] What is the purpose of `--build-require` argument?
issue.body:
### What is your question?

I don't understand what using `--build-require` does to a conan create. I read the documentation (https://docs.conan.io/2/reference/commands/create.html?highlight=--format#using-conan-create-with-build-requirements), which states that it

> allows to create the package using the configuration and settings of the “build” context, as it was a build_require 

but I don't really get what implications that has.

### Have you read the CONTRIBUTING guide?

- [ ] I've read the CONTRIBUTING guide

issue.title: [question] VirtualRunEnv does not take tool_requires into account?
issue.body:
### What is your question?

Hi, I am currently migrating to Conan 2 (i.e. 2.0.12) and facing issues with the `VirtualRunEnv` generator when using `gcc` as a conan package which is obviously needed in the `buildenv` but also in the `runenv`, since it also provides libs like e.g. `libstdc++.so` and the like. 
My understanding was that in Conan 2 the generator automatically takes care of propagating `libdirs` to `LD_LIBRARY_PATH` in the `runenv`. But this is apparently not the case for `tool_requires`, although I expected this to be the reason why `tool_requires` sets the trait `run=True`.

Specifically I first encountered the issue when building `geographiclib` (https://github.com/conan-io/conan-center-index/blob/master/recipes/geographiclib/all/test_package/conanfile.py). I provide the compiler dependency using a profile like this:
```
[settings]
compiler=gcc
compiler.version=11.4
compiler.libcxx=libstdc++11

[tool_requires]
gcc/11.4.0@me/testing
```

Building `geographiclib` works fine, but executing the test package leads to the following error:

```
======== Testing the package: Executing test ========
geographiclib/1.52@me/testing (test package): Running test()
geographiclib/1.52@me/testing (test package): RUN: ./test_package
./test_package: /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libstdc++.so.6: version `GLIBCXX_3.4.29' not found (required by /home/me/.conan2/p/b/geogr35b2f1e80aeb9/p/lib/libGeographic.so.19)

ERROR: geographiclib/1.52@me/testing (test package): Error in test() method, line 26
        self.run(bin_path, env="conanrun")
        ConanException: Error 1 while executing
```

Obviously the `libdir` of `gcc` is not part of the `LD_LIBRARY_PATH` and instead of the `libstdc++.so` provided by the conan package the system one is found during runtime, which does not match the version from compilation.

This can be mitigated by hacking an explicit runtime dependency into the test package like `self.requires("gcc/11.4.0@me/stable", run=True)`. Then executing the test executable in the `conanrun` env works. But this is just a hack.

From looking at the code in `conan/tools/env/virtualrunenv.py` in the `environment()` method, I see that only `host` and `test` dependencies are taken into account for the env: 

```
        host_req = self._conanfile.dependencies.host
        test_req = self._conanfile.dependencies.test
        for require, dep in list(host_req.items()) + list(test_req.items()):
            if dep.runenv_info:
                runenv.compose_env(dep.runenv_info)
            if require.run:  # Only if the require is run (shared or application to be run)
                _os = self._conanfile.settings.get_safe("os")
                runenv.compose_env(runenv_from_cpp_info(dep, _os))
```

But those `host` and `test` properties directly filter for `build=False` which obviously does not take `tool_requires` into account which use `build=True`. See `conans/model/dependencies.py` line 138:

```
    @property
    def host(self):
        return self.filter({"build": False, "test": False, "skip": False})

    @property
    def test(self):
        # Not needed a direct_test because they are visible=False so only the direct consumer
        # will have them in the graph
        return self.filter({"build": False, "test": True, "skip": False})
```

Now, is there a misunderstanding on my side? I would have expected that since `tool_requires` sets `run=True`, those should also be reflected in the `VirtualRunEnv`. Generally I think all dependecies with `run=True` should be reflected in the `VirtualRunEnv`.
Indeed changing the code in `conan/tools/env/virtualrunenv.py` to something like this, makes is work as I expected:
```
        host_req = self._conanfile.dependencies.host
        test_req = self._conanfile.dependencies.test
        run_req = self._conanfile.dependencies.filter({"run": True})
        for require, dep in list(host_req.items()) + list(test_req.items()) + list(run_req.items()):
            if dep.runenv_info:
                runenv.compose_env(dep.runenv_info)
            if require.run:  # Only if the require is run (shared or application to be run)
                _os = self._conanfile.settings.get_safe("os")
                runenv.compose_env(runenv_from_cpp_info(dep, _os))
```

What is the best practice here for dependencies needed during build and run?

### Have you read the CONTRIBUTING guide?

- [X] I've read the CONTRIBUTING guide

comment.body:
> You might with a small cheat, avoid that. Like using the tool_requires in the profile, and just running a conan install --requires=gcc/... -g VirtualRunEnv to get the extra env script to inject that runtime? Might need some exploration.

Thank you @memsharded ! This might in fact be a workaround for now. I will give it a try.

Thank you also for giving the "toolchain-requires" concept some more thought. I believe this is a fundamental issue in the C/C++ world and conan needs to address this in some more user-friendly way. 

I didn't mean to be rude or anything with that comment about the broken gcc package. It just startled me that this package is apparently barely used. Or probably most people just take that as a starting point and "fix" the official recipe locally to their custom needs (like I did)...

issue.title: Feature/premake
issue.body:
**Feature**: Premake5 tool for Conan2

**Changelog**:

I have changed the implementation of the `Premake` tool to properly support the invocation of premake5 based on the conanfile and optional parameters. It's now also possible to directly call build on the `Premake` object. The build function will forward the call based on the OS and target configurations (`MSBuild` on Windows, `XcodeBuild` on OSX and a direkt `make` call on Linux)

The next step for better premake5 support would now be a proper package that exposes the premake5 executable. Maybe it's possible to adapt [the existing one](https://github.com/conan-io/conan-center-index/blob/master/recipes/premake/5.x/conanfile.py) or implement a new one `premake5-prebuild`. I had my issues with the existing one back in conan 1.x days (As it seems the build is not integrating all required resources, and thus the executable was not able to correctly generate project files), and now it's also not even 2.x compatible, and the premake version is outdated. Since premake5 offers a ready-to-use pre-build version for all compatible systems on their homepage, i don't see the point in compiling it on the conan infrastructure. 

**Docs**: 

Please let me know as soon as we can move forward towards documentation and proper support of premake5. Currently, I see the following things holding us back:

- Feedback on what it takes to properly add documented support 
- Premake5 conan2 compatible package on conan-center-index (I will probably try to take a look at this soon) so that preamke5 is not required in the system's path
- Proper unit testing of the `Premake` tool and the `PremakeDeps` generator.
- Documentation of the integration

**Checklist**:

- [x] Refer to the issue that supports this Pull Request.
- [x] If the issue has missing info, explain the purpose/use case/pain/need that covers this Pull Request.
- [x] I've read the [Contributing guide](https://github.com/conan-io/conan/blob/develop/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md).
- [x] I've followed the PEP8 style guides for Python code.
- [ ] I've opened another PR in the Conan docs repo to the ``develop`` branch, documenting this one.

comment.body: @memsharded thank you for the feedback. Sorry im currently quit occupied and will try to get back as soon as possible to this.

issue.title: install shared and static libs
issue.body:
### What is your question?

Hi,

My understanding of installing shared and static libs from conan center: To install shared lib, profile should have following

[options]
shared=True

If this is not mentioned in profile, then static lib will be installed. 
Please correct me if my understanding is wrong.
Question : Is there a way to install both -- static and shared libs using same profile?

Best Regards
Laxmi


### Have you read the CONTRIBUTING guide?

- [ ] I've read the CONTRIBUTING guide

issue.title: Conan config install failing randomly for parallel builds.
issue.body:
Hi, 

Conan config install is failing randomly for parallel builds. 

Command used: conan config install ${ARTIFACTORY_BASEURL}/artifactory/conanrepo/config.zip
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
[2023-10-24T23:42:43.945Z] Trying to download  https://artifactory-pd.com/artifactory/conanrepo/config.zip
[2023-10-24T23:42:43.945Z] ERROR: Failed conan config install: Error while installing config from https://artifactory-pd.com/artifactory/conanrepo/config.zip
[2023-10-24T23:42:43.945Z] [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/home/bangbuild/.conan/tmp_config_install/config.zip'
script returned exit code 1

oR 

[2023-10-24T17:45:47.087Z] ERROR: Failed conan config install: [Errno 17] File exists: '/home/bangbuild/.conan/tmp_config_install'
script returned exit code 1

We are running builds in parallel inside docker containers. Conan cache is under /home/bangbuild (/home/bangbuild path in host is mounted inside the Docker container).

Regards,
Mohan 




### Have you read the CONTRIBUTING guide?

- [ ] I've read the CONTRIBUTING guide

comment.body:
So, the only option is to export the CONAN_USER_HOME variable in our script/Jenkins pipelines. Is this understanding correct?
Kindly confirm.

issue.title: [question] With MsBuild Conan is not able to find msbuild
issue.body:
### What is your question?

Hi,

I am using Conan version 2.0.13. 
I am trying to build a project using Visual Studio. The build in the recipe is simple : 
```
def build(self):
        msbuild = MSBuild(self)
        msbuild.build("my_solution.sln")
```

When I try to create the package, I get this error : 
```
legacy-core-hmi/0.0.0: Calling build()
legacy-core-hmi/0.0.0: RUN: msbuild "my_solution.sln" /p:Configuration="Release" /p:Platform=x86
'msbuild' is not recognized as an internal or external command,
operable program or batch file.
```


I am not sure that I understand why Conan does not find msbuild. I have other project that use CMake and Conan builds those projects correctly.

I am using Visual Studio 2022. (C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\2022\Professional)

My profile is this : 
```
[settings]
arch=x86
build_type=Release
compiler=msvc
compiler.runtime=dynamic
compiler.version=193
compiler.cppstd=14
os=Windows
```

Note: If I manually run `vcvars` before the `conan create`, the build completes successfully

Thanks :)

### Have you read the CONTRIBUTING guide?

- [X] I've read the CONTRIBUTING guide

comment.body:
Hi @memsharded 

Thank you for your really quick reply 😄 

I added the `generators = "MSBuildToolchain"` line and it does fix the issue with Conan not setting up the Visual Studio environment during the build.

issue.title: [feature] package_info/CMakeDeps: provide a way to propagate interface C and C++ min standard (c_std_yy/cxx_std_yy) in imported targets
issue.body:
<!-- What is your suggestion? Please be as specific as possible! -->

- [x] I've read the [CONTRIBUTING guide](https://github.com/conan-io/conan/blob/develop/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md).

Properly written CMakeLists of C and C++ libraries propagate interface c_std & cxx_std compile feature in imported targets. It would be nice if there was a way to properly set this compile feature in `package_info()` so that imported targets in `CMakeDeps` inherit this useful information.

For example:

```python
def package_info(self):
    self.cpp_info.set_property("cmake_target_name", "foo::bar")
    self.cpp_info.set_property("cmake_compile_features", ["cxx_std_17"])
```

then in config file generated by `CMakeDeps` there would be:

```cmake
set_target_properties(foo::bar PROPERTIES INTERFACE_COMPILE_FEATURES "cxx_std_17")
```

comment.body:
Hi @ilya-lavrenov 

I have reviewed https://github.com/conan-io/conan-center-index/pull/20774#pullrequestreview-1700714667.

The approach that conan follows is not propagating cppstd requirements down the graph, but the ``cppstd`` is an input definition, and as such, recipes should use it, or raise a ``ConanInvalidConfiguration`` error if not possible. The ``settings.compiler.cppstd`` should be defined in Conan 2.0, it is not recommended to not specify it.

issue.title: [question] With MsBuild Conan is not able to find msbuild
issue.body:
### What is your question?

Hi,

I am using Conan version 2.0.13. 
I am trying to build a project using Visual Studio. The build in the recipe is simple : 
```
def build(self):
        msbuild = MSBuild(self)
        msbuild.build("my_solution.sln")
```

When I try to create the package, I get this error : 
```
legacy-core-hmi/0.0.0: Calling build()
legacy-core-hmi/0.0.0: RUN: msbuild "my_solution.sln" /p:Configuration="Release" /p:Platform=x86
'msbuild' is not recognized as an internal or external command,
operable program or batch file.
```


I am not sure that I understand why Conan does not find msbuild. I have other project that use CMake and Conan builds those projects correctly.

I am using Visual Studio 2022. (C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\2022\Professional)

My profile is this : 
```
[settings]
arch=x86
build_type=Release
compiler=msvc
compiler.runtime=dynamic
compiler.version=193
compiler.cppstd=14
os=Windows
```

Note: If I manually run `vcvars` before the `conan create`, the build completes successfully

Thanks :)

### Have you read the CONTRIBUTING guide?

- [X] I've read the CONTRIBUTING guide

comment.body:
Hi @DominicPicard 

Thanks for your question.
This is expected:
- CMake contains internal logic to find ``msbuild`` when ``-G Visual Studio xxxx`` is passed. Conan just call cmake and it happens
- If you type ``msbuild`` in the terminal, it fails, unless you activate the vcvars.
- Conan does not try to be smart and activate or setup the environment based on the settings. This has to be defined by the recipes.
- This would be the responsibility of the ``MSBuildToolchain``. If you use it, you'll see that it will create a ``conanvcvars.bat`` that contains the command to activate the VS. Furthermore, this ``conanvcvars`` will be automatically call from ``conanbuild.bat`` that is automatically called for every ``self.run()`` command, including commands like ``msbuild.build()`` that calls internally ``self.run()``
- The ``MSBuildToolchain`` also generates a ``conantoolchain.props`` file, with information about the toolset or cppstd that can be used to introduce variability, build different binary variant depending on the Conan input settings. This file must be included from your .vcxproj file

Please let me know if this helps.

comment.body:
Ok, so the PR seems good, and the patch that is still missing seems something on the CMake side, not something that Conan should fix, but if you think it would be easy to add something to the ``CMakeToolchain`` that automatically adds ``set(CMAKE_${lang}_OSX_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET_FLAG "")`` conditioned on the ``VisionOS`` and that could work, that could be added, feel free to open another PR if you'd like. 

I am merging this, thanks very much!

issue.title: Conan config install failing randomly for parallel builds.
issue.body:
Hi, 

Conan config install is failing randomly for parallel builds. 

Command used: conan config install ${ARTIFACTORY_BASEURL}/artifactory/conanrepo/config.zip
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
[2023-10-24T23:42:43.945Z] Trying to download  https://artifactory-pd.com/artifactory/conanrepo/config.zip
[2023-10-24T23:42:43.945Z] ERROR: Failed conan config install: Error while installing config from https://artifactory-pd.com/artifactory/conanrepo/config.zip
[2023-10-24T23:42:43.945Z] [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/home/bangbuild/.conan/tmp_config_install/config.zip'
script returned exit code 1

oR 

[2023-10-24T17:45:47.087Z] ERROR: Failed conan config install: [Errno 17] File exists: '/home/bangbuild/.conan/tmp_config_install'
script returned exit code 1

We are running builds in parallel inside docker containers. Conan cache is under /home/bangbuild (/home/bangbuild path in host is mounted inside the Docker container).

Regards,
Mohan 




### Have you read the CONTRIBUTING guide?

- [ ] I've read the CONTRIBUTING guide

comment.body:
Hi @mkjkec2005 

Thanks for your feedback.
This is expected, the Conan cache is not designed for concurrency. Every job should have its own cache, or run sequentially.

Conan 1.X had some limited support for a few operations, but ``conan config install`` was not one of them. Conan 2.0 doesn't have any concurrency support (you might find this explicitly stated in https://docs.conan.io/2/knowledge/guidelines.html), but it is planned to try to add them in the close future.

issue.title: Fix min target flag for xros and xros-simulator
issue.body:
Changelog: Bugfix

Apple changes the way the "min target os version" flag is created
Docs: https://developer.apple.com/forums/thread/737595

This fixes the generation of the min target version flag for visionsOS and visionsOS simulator

comment.body:
Yes for me this is working.
Luckily with Xcode 15.1 Beta Apple has **removed** the x86_64 target 
-target **_x86_64_**-apple-xros1.0 
and we no longer need the arch parameter I mentioned earlier and the PR is  perfectly fine yet.

But there is still a unfixed issue in cmake 3.28rc2.
It is not possible to build cmake based libs with conan and cmake for visionOS simulator without patching 

Apple-Clang.cmake
```
....
  elseif(_CMAKE_OSX_SYSROOT_PATH MATCHES "/XRSimulator")
    set(CMAKE_${lang}_OSX_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET_FLAG "")
....
```

and replacing the flag with an empty string

issue.body:

issue.title: [question] Conan cross compilation MacOS to RaspberryPi
issue.body:
<!-- What is your question? Please be as specific as possible! -->
Hello,

I have 2 questions for you.

Does Conan support cross compilation from MacOS to Raspberry Pi? 

Is there example code for the talk **Continuous Integration of C/C++ Apps for IoT Devices** by Diego Rodriguez-Losada & Daniel Manzaneque in 2018?

I have read through the examples that are listed on the cross compile portion of the website and I do not see anything about MacOS targeting Raspberry Pi, Linux, or Windows.

I want to recreate the cross compilation example that was presented at the **Continuous Integration of C/C++ Apps for IoT Devices** by Diego Rodriguez-Losada & Daniel Manzaneque in 2018, but use MacOS instead of Windows.

- [ X ] I've read the [CONTRIBUTING guide](https://github.com/conan-io/conan/blob/develop/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md).

issue.title: [bug] Bazel generator ignores binaries/executables in a package
issue.body:
### Environment details

* Operating System+version: Any
* Compiler+version: Any 
* Conan version: 1.59, very likely all others also
* Python version: Any


### Steps to reproduce

When using protobuf, for example, the generated BUILD file looks like followed:

```
load("@rules_cc//cc:defs.bzl", "cc_import", "cc_library")

cc_import(
    name = "protoc_precompiled",
    static_library = "lib/libprotoc.a",
)

cc_import(
    name = "protobuf_precompiled",
    static_library = "lib/libprotobuf.a",
)

cc_library(
    name = "protobuf",
    hdrs = glob(["include/**"]),
    includes = ["include"],
    visibility = ["//visibility:public"],
    deps = [
        # do not sort
        ":protoc_precompiled",
        ":protobuf_precompiled",
    ],
)
```

That is correct for the static library part. 
But protobuf also comes with a binary, `protoc` , and this file is lost. 

Maybe there should be at least a bazel `filegroup`, exposing the binary (binaries)

```
filegroup(
    name = "protoc",
    srcs = ["bin/protoc"],
    visibility = ["//visibility:public"],
)
```

for the binary can be accessed, and a user can make their `sh_binary` wrapper or whatever in bazel

---
This is, btw, also missing for dynamic libraries, which also needs to be put in place by bazel. I needed to patch every generated BUILD file to add that, so just for the few exceptions I have with dynamic libraries,  there is a file group and user can care about that they get placed on the right location fir executables to find them. 
But that should possible be an extra issue? Nor sure, its very related 



### Logs

_No response_

comment.body:
Awesome, good to see that the existing Conan 1 users still get some love !

Thank you!
